org.microbean.jersey.netty

Class NettyContainerResponseWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.microbean.jersey.netty.NettyContainerResponseWriter
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ContainerResponseWriter

    public class NettyContainerResponseWriter
extends Object
implements ContainerResponseWriter
    A ContainerResponseWriter that takes care not to block the Netty event loop.
    Author:
    Laird Nelson
    See Also:
    ContainerResponseWriter, writeResponseStatusAndHeaders(long, ContainerResponse), createChunkedInput(EventExecutor, ByteBuf, long)

      • createChunkedInput

        protected ChunkedInput<?> createChunkedInput(EventExecutor eventExecutor,
                                             ByteBuf source,
                                             long contentLength)
        Creates a new ChunkedInput instance whose ChunkedInput.readChunk(ByteBufAllocator) method will stream ByteBuf chunks to the Netty transport.

        This method never returns null.

        In normal usage this method will be invoked on a thread that is not in the Netty event loop. Care must be taken if an override of this method decides to invoke any methods on the supplied ByteBuf to ensure those methods are invoked in the Netty event loop. This implementation does not invoke any ByteBuf methods and overrides are strongly urged to follow suit.

        Overrides of this method must not return null.

        This method is called from the writeResponseStatusAndHeaders(long, ContainerResponse) method. Overrides must not call that method or an infinite loop may result.

        Parameters:
        eventExecutor - an EventExecutor, supplied for convenience, that can be used to ensure certain tasks are executed in the Netty event loop; must not be null
        source - the ByteBuf, which might be mutating in the Netty event loop, that the returned ChunkedInput should read from in some way when its ChunkedInput.readChunk(ByteBufAllocator) method is called from the Netty event loop; must not be null
        contentLength - a long representing the value of any Content-Length header that might have been present; it is guaranteed that when this method is invoked by the default implementation of the writeResponseStatusAndHeaders(long, ContainerResponse) method this parameter will never be 0L but might very well be less than 0L to indicate an unknown content length
        Returns:
        a new ChunkedInput that reads in some way from the supplied source when its ChunkedInput.readChunk(ByteBufAllocator) method is called from the Netty event loop; never null
        See Also:
        ByteBufChunkedInput.ByteBufChunkedInput(ByteBuf, long), ChunkedInput.readChunk(ByteBufAllocator)

      • commit

        public final void commit()
        Invoked on a non-event-loop thread by Jersey when, as far as Jersey is concerned, all processing has completed successfully.

        This implementation ensures that ChunkedInput.close() is called on the Netty event loop on the ChunkedInput returned by the createChunkedInput(EventExecutor, ByteBuf, long) method, and that a LastHttpContent.EMPTY_LAST_CONTENT message is written immediately afterwards, and that the ChannelHandlerContext is flushed. All of these invocations occur on the event loop.

        Specified by:
        commit in interface ContainerResponseWriter
        See Also:
        ChunkedInput.close(), createChunkedInput(EventExecutor, ByteBuf, long), LastHttpContent.EMPTY_LAST_CONTENT, ChannelOutboundInvoker.write(Object), ChannelHandlerContext.flush(), ContainerResponseWriter.commit()

      • failure

        public void failure(Throwable throwable)
        Invoked on a non-event-loop thread by Jersey when, as far as Jersey is concerned, all processing has completed unsuccessfully.
        Specified by:
        failure in interface ContainerResponseWriter
        Parameters:
        throwable - the Throwable that caused failure; strictly speaking may be null
        Throws:
        RuntimeException - if an error occurs while processing the supplied Throwable; the supplied Throwable will be added as a suppressed Throwable
        Error - if an error occurs while processing the supplied Throwable; the supplied Throwable will be added as a suppressed Throwable
        See Also:
        ContainerResponseWriter.failure(Throwable)

      • enableResponseBuffering

        public boolean enableResponseBuffering()
        Returns true when invoked.

        Note that this is a default value. Response buffering can be configured.

        Specified by:
        enableResponseBuffering in interface ContainerResponseWriter
        Returns:
        true when invoked
        See Also:
        ContainerResponseWriter.enableResponseBuffering(), ContainerResponse.java, OutboundMessageContext.java
